    • Method Detail

      • getAxisCategories

        public static java.lang.Number[] getAxisCategories(java.lang.Number start,
                                   java.lang.Number end)
        calculates the optimal division of a a range of number into a reasonable amount of axis categories.
        Example: if the x-axis of a graph should run from 0 to 1000, how to divide this into a reasonable number of ticks over the x-axis? Clearly not all 1000 points can be drawn. The method takes the start and end value of the x-axis domain, and calculates what the x-axis ticks should show to get not too many, and not too few points. Makes use of the FACTORS constant.
        Tested up to a range of a million wide, but should theoretically work up to infinity (so for any range).
        Parameters:
        start - a Number indicating the start of the x-axis range.
        end - a Number indicating the end of the x-axis range. Swapping with start (so start is the highest and end is the lowest value) is no problem.
        Returns:
        a range of number to be put on the x-axis of the graph, in one array of numbers.

      • getOptimalRangeAround

        public static java.lang.Number[] getOptimalRangeAround(java.lang.Number midPoint,
                                       double percentile,
                                       int precision,
                                       double rangeWidth,
                                       java.lang.Double lowerLimit)
        Creates a nice range around a "midpoint", based on the optimum number of points along the x-axis. The created range will have a width 80% of the maximum width as defined in 
         MAX_X_RANGE_VALUE
        .
        Parameters:
        midPoint - a Number, being the point around which the range is built. Note that this method only makes much sense when midPoint is an integer.
        percentile - a double; the midPoint is on the 
         percentile
        percentile of the range. Example: if percentile is 33, the "midPoint" is on 1/3 of the range, having 1/3 of the points smaller, and 2/3 of the points larger than midPoint.
        precision - an int indicating the scale factor. A MidPoint of 0 and a percentile of 50 creates -9, -8 ... 0.. 8, 9 when scaling is 0; it creates -90, -80... 80, 90 when scaling is 1. Scaling may be negative too.
        rangeWidth - a double indicating the width of the range, as a fraction of the maximum range width MAX_X_RANGE_VALUE. A value of 0.8 means that the rangeWidth is 80% of the max range width. From this, it follows that values must be between 0 and 1, or else an IllegalArgumenException is thrown.
        lowerLimit - a Double indicating the lowest value a point in the range can get. Any points in the range lower than this limit are just skipped / left out. This parameter may be null, which means that it is just ignored.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if rangeWidth < 0 or > 1; and if percentile < 0 or > 100
